newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Golden Harvest in US$30.0 mln film fund.
newsitem.headline: Golden Harvest in US$30.0 mln film fund.

text.p: A US$30.0 million investment fund to make films for the China market was launched on Monday by a multinational group of companies.
Hong Kong-based film company Golden Harvest, Citicorp unit Citicorp Capital Asia Ltd and government-owned Television Corporation of Singapore (TCS) announced the fund, GH Pictures (China) Ltd.
It aims to "tap international capital and resources to help support the growth of the movie industry in China", said Raymond Chow, chairman of Golden Harvest Entertainment Holdings Ltd.
China is among the biggest movie markets in the world and demand for film entertainment is immense, Chow told a news conference.
Eight projects have already been identified for investment by the fund, he said. Two movies have been completed, two are in production and four more are in pre-production.
The fund, subscribed to in equal segments of US$10.0 million by each of the three partners, could soon be expanded to US$60.0 million, said Vincent Fan, chief executive of Citicorp Capital Asia.
"We have kicked off with US$30.0 million but our ambition is bigger. The market could easily use up another US$30.0 million," Fan said.
Citicorp's involvement in the deal is through a partnership with insurance company Metlife Investments Asia Ltd in which both companies contributed US$5.0 million.
TCS is involved in partnership with the Singapore government's Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd.
The partners said the fund was a long term investment project. No details of its projected life span or potential partners in future fund raising exercises were given.
